If foreign ocean shippers are going to utilize American ports, they need to play by our rules. The Ocean Shipping Reform Act establishes needed rules of the road for importing and exporting. https://640q92ead86zzcx32uoxzyzz-wpengine.netdna-ssl.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/AgTC-Statement-Enactment-of-OSRA2022.2pdf.pdf

The Garamendi-Johnson Ocean Shipping Reform Act passed the House overwhelmingly for the first time in December 2021‚Äîit's the first major update to our maritime laws since 1998. Then came the Senate companion in February 2022.
U.S. dairy producers lost more than $1.3 billion in export revenue in the first three quarters of 2021. This hurts the American economy and risks our reputation as a reliable trade partner overseas.

Equally as troubling, U.S. producers and shippers have been subject to millions in "detention and demurrage" fees because of carrier cancelations. If carriers cancel on U.S. biz, why are we getting fined for it? Our bill cracks down on this practice.

According to @FarmBureau, the U.S. has lost out on more than $25 billion in agricultural exports in the last six months because of ocean shipping constraints. OSRA ensures foreign ocean carriers can't take advantage of U.S. ports, while abandoning our products at the dock.

A coalition of House members started asking questions and made an inquiry to the @FMCSA about these allegations. We learned they lacked the enforcement to crack down on these unfair practices‚Äîthis is when OSRA was born. https://agriculture.house.gov/uploadedfiles/03.09.2021_fmc_vocc_letter.pdf?utm_campaign=834-520

Consumer spending on e-commerce hit record numbers last year. China began incentivizing foreign ocean carriers to drop their loads at the dock, ditch American food exports, and return to Asia w/empty containers. We heard from U.S. biz in March 2021 about this unfair behavior.

Our supply chain continues to face significant problems ‚Äì the Ocean Shipping Reform Act will provide the relief U.S. exporters so desperately need. More than 450 U.S. groups back our bill ‚Äì looking forward to seeing it signed into law TODAY. Here‚Äôs why we introduced OSRA‚§µÔ∏è

It may seem like the conflict in Ukraine is fading into the background, but this is fundamental. Whether you're a staunch believer in preserving democracy or just want to protect the pocketbooks of the American people, ramping up in the near term needs to be a top priority. 14/14

And if the grain doesn't get out, the U.S. & others will be paying for Russian aggression ‚Äî not just in our own skyrocketing food & gas prices, but also to manage the fallout in conflicts around the globe in starving or destabilized countries. 13/14

But here's the rub: if the Ukrainians lose ground over the summer, they are unlikely to go to the negotiating table ‚Äî it becomes a frozen conflict that's terrible for them and terrible for the international community. 12/14
All options should be on the table to respond ‚Äî including a humanitarian escort involving NATO or other Black Sea countries ‚Äî to protect commercial shipping so we can get that grain moving. 11/14

Negotiations are ideal, but we need to get creative & specific about which country (or countries) could provide security for ships carrying grain. Putin has effectively internationalized his war, making millions of people around the world the victims of Russia's aggression. 10/14

On the question of Ukrainian grain, I hope that serious conversations are happening in the Situation Room and within the international community on what specifically we can do to get that grain out of Ukrainian ports. 9/14

So what can we do? It‚Äôs clear we need to speed up our support. Whether it's hastening the shipments of promised weapons or identifying longer-range systems, we have a very limited window ‚Äî essentially this summer ‚Äî to help the Ukrainians compete and advance. 8/14

I understand the admin's concerns that providing long-range weapons risks escalation, but the Ukrainians have & should continue to commit to using them only in defending their territory ‚Äî not targeting Russia. But they need to be able to compete against Russian advantages. 7/14

The Ukrainians can only stomach coming to the table if *they* have military victories under their belt. And right now, the outlook isn't ideal. After their remarkable showing at the start of the war, they need expedited materiel now ‚Äî including longer range weapons. 6/14
For both these reasons, it is to Russia‚Äôs advantage to wait us out, secure the narrow military victories they can, and only come to the negotiating table if they have the clear advantage. 5/14
